New Records: Nedim Bajrami set a new record for the fastest goal scored in European Championship history when opening the scoring against Italy.
Key Match Events: Qazim Laci nodded in a superb cross from Jasir Asani in the 11th minute to open the scoring
Kristjan Asllani went off-target following a quick attacking move sparked by Modric losing the ball
Rey Manaj failed to get a proper connection on a header
Croatia equalised in the 74th minute through Andrej Kramaric
Ante Budimir teed up Kramaric for their equaliser
Klaus Gjasula turned in a cross intended for Luka Sucic
Mitaj pulled back a wonderful low cross for Gjasula in stoppage time
Pre-Game Insights: Sylvinho’s side finds a way to forge its own path through the tournament; one that frequently sees it roughing up bigger and more established football players.
Mario Mandzukic could be seen leaping from the dugout to demand his players match Albania’s intensity in the first half
Sylvinho’s decision to leave regulars Myrto Uzuni, Keidi Bare and Sokol Cikalleshi out of the 26-man squad for the tournament caused a stir
Post-Match Reflections: We have to fight for every point,” was Sylvinho’s post-match assessment of the game. “For our country and for our federation.
Sylvinho often makes mention of sweat and respect in press conferences. Hard work is the bare minimum and the most important ingredient for this Albania side.
Gjasula — only the second player to score an own goal and a goal within the same game at the Euros — had given his side a slender chance of making it to the round of 16.
Miscellaneous Highlights: It took 23 seconds for this side to make a mark at Euro 2024 as Nedim Bajrami set a new record for the fastest goal scored in European Championship history
Albania could have collapsed, but they somehow found a second wind
Sylvinho and his staff celebrate Albania’s draw
